I am a 44 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. My son recently started this game and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Tiktok. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, did the tutorial but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Decided to add my favorite competitive pvp game. I played since the beginning of beta throughout the years on Xbox then PC. Although I haven't touched the last year or so. Because there has been lots of changes and updates to the game.
The game is described as a love/hate relationship & it's best described as a search & destroy game (COD). So throughout the past years and now...the game is continuing to add more new operators, maps, and adjust/nerf features... I used to play with friends, but that stopped due to things. The game can rage in ranked when your up and you somehow lose at the end. They added other modes including AI vs which is step in community audience direction. Siege still needs more changes through feedback to avoid cheaters and support. I do recommend this game. I recommend it more if you can play with your friends than randoms. I do wish my friends would play this game but... I doubt they will. And that being said...I hope one day siege will beat higher PVP shooters games like Apex & Counter-strike (free games) in active players. But there needs more changes to make that happen...

I miss what this game used to be. (A brief rant)

From year one to three this game used to be so much more simple and enjoyable. The atmosphere has completely changed and the game just feels like a sweatfest where everyone plays their absolute hardest using the meta, exploits, toxicity and other crap game mechanics to their advantage. For context I have been playing this game on and off since beta and have logged thousands of hours across multiple platforms. I was hooked on the game ever since the beta. But as time goes on I play this game less and less and every time I return after awhile it always makes me so disappointed.

They have mutilated all of the classic maps, operators have completely been reworked (some for the better admittedly) and the core game mechanics are different every time I boot up this game. I'm not afraid of change but this games identity, gameplay and overall "feel" has been completely tarnished and turned into this ultimate competitive cash cow that gets worse with every season.

Something that really upsets and confuses me is the removal of T-Hunt. T-Hunt was an amazing gamemode that was perfect for putting on music and practising the mechanics of the game. Learning that they removed it was shocking and when I tried the horribly made practice game mode they threw together to take its place made me immediately Alt+F4 and write this review.

And that's not even the worse part. The entire game is just a mess and I could go on all day verbally about how awfully this game feels compared to what it once was but just don't care enough to write much more about how I feel.

It's just super saddening to see what was for a long time my absolute favourite game just get run into the dirt. Ever since Operation Grim Sky this game started going down the shit pipe and it will sadly never be the same again.  

If you were playing from Operation Velvet Shell to Operation Para Bellum congratulations, you were playing during this games golden era. If you missed that time, I genuinely feel bad for you. This game sucks now.

I don't typically play games like this, only close thing was Overwatch when I was younger. But my brother got me into watching Jynxzi a few months ago and inspired me to actually play Rainbow Six Siege (besides a week when I was in 9th grade).

There's clearly been a lot attention to detail, with a wide away of operators (playable characters) to suit different play styles. Also love the diverse set of operators. They come from around the world. Can't forget to mention the maps, honestly probably the best part of the game. Each includes many breakable surfaces so it offers and rewards creative ways to navigate and get kills. The actual objectives are pretty simple but the different match ups and maps make for a great experience. 

The game play is pretty standard for an fps shooter. Some gun customization is pretty cool, affecting the recoil which, to my knowledge, I don't pay attention to or haven't seen in other shooters. The biggest thing though is the skill ceiling. Like said before, many operators; so you gotta eventually learn to play or go against, getting accustomed to changing environments, the different map layouts, and remembering to listen to your surrounds. 

I'm obviously not the first to start playing because of Jynxzi and I'm still a noob, but honestly R6 is a solid game, 8.5/10.

I have died so many times in this game...
as warden...
as mozzie...
I've begun to long for that to happen to me, the purity of death, my final breaths... in out in out... the death rattle my body makes as the excess oxygen leaves my body during decomposition, the maggots rummaging through my organs to feast upon my drying blood inside me... the slimy sound of maggots hitting they're disgusting worm like bodies together as they get the fill of blood they need to survive...
my brain deteriorating to eventually slowly drain out of an ear or to slug its way down out my nose and mouth... my beating heart stopped long ago, losing its rhythm and stopping itself as if it has lost purpose, sad and alone, it seeks refuge with my lungs, until the lungs slop off its cords to fall down and seep with my rotting corpse...
I wish someone would kill me, I only need it once, I want to expire by someone, anyone's hands, with my blood staining them with hellish red, I want you to laugh and torture me, i want to be gutted i want you to play with my recently deceased corpse...
To die at someones hands for me is like having your first kiss, flutters of excitement, happiness and a sense of fullness.
of course for a dead body and decaying corpse, it isn't going to feel full, after being gutted with rusty blades and medical tools...
I want to die, I want to die with one. just one, i ask for death, for the gates of the end shall be stood high above me, forever a lost soul, forever in pain....

This game saved my life.

I am 27.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

- When you play ranked, just know you will be matched against people who will have more knowledge of the game than you. This is like every other FPS - you will have smurfs. The key factors in this game is ( tactics, Communication, teamwork, gunplay) 
END - I like this game but it needs an active development groups, that isn't afraid to just rework the game with CENTRAL IDEA of what they want. There seems to no coordination where the development team wants to go. That is all from my perspective. MY PERSPECTIVE CAN BE WRONG.

When you purchase anything, it would be unacceptable if the thing you purchased suddenly changed and was no longer that original thing. If the product was no longer the same product you bought; even if the company who sold you the product claimed that this was the "new" "updated" version, you would be upset, right?. I bought this game because I am a fan of the original Tom Clancy games. When I bought this game, Terrorist Hunt was part of the game. How is it acceptable for a company to change the game you "bought" and eliminate features such as Terrorist Hunt? This practice is completely anti-consumer, and a reminder to all, that you don't own any of these games. If ubisoft wanted to add features to this game, while still keeping what was there, that would be fine, but we should still have the option to play the game the way it was sold to us.

R6 Siege... an interesting game. As of right now, it is Wednesday. I got this game saturday night and played for an hour and a half. now I almost have an entire day on this game. It's saddening how woke this steaming pile of trash has become. I do not want to play as an single-looking, unattractive 38-year-old mom or a bald black woman talking like a edgy male Londoner. I don't like the "balancing of the game" either. It just makes it less fun to play. Underpowering shotguns, operators and changing iconic free-for-all maps like House all for the sake of "balance." It just makes the game feel more robotic and sweaty and that's not fun to me. I'm happy to say I've permanently removed Siege from my library despite my countless hours playing the game from 2016 to 2019, and I won't be buying it ever again.

It's a very fun and wildly deep FPS game, there's just so much coolness you can do here (breaching walls, cameras, drones, attachments, all the abilities...) that you don't really find elsewhere, it's fun to host private game matches and do 2v2's and stuff, and I do recommend the game, but...

The downfall of what used to be the best competitive shooter is just sad now.

Ranked 2.0 has ruined the games enjoyment for me. In a competitive game rank no longer means anything or gives you an indication to skill level. Cheaters and John Wick's are in every ranked game now, even if you haven't played in about 25 years. I'm not entirely sure what hidden mmr is based off of but doesn't it defeat the whole purpose of having an elo system in the game. If i am stuck in plat I want to consider myself a plat player and try and improve and get to the next rank, now I start in copper and go against champ players, guess i am a copper player now. Ranked is now just play for rewards rather than improving and the TDM ADHD meta is in full force.

Casual has been completely revamped with core 'casual' aspects like non competitive maps and freedom to strategise however you want has been ruined. Pre placed rotates and reinforcements and reworking a map like house to make it more competitive in a CASUAL gamemode makes no sense. 

The gunplay now is gradually being ruined, is this gun too popular compared to another? Increase the recoil instead of buffing the guns that don't get played to reduce the pick rate. Making guns that people have fun using less fun does not make the game more enjoyable. The 1.5x scope is one of the worst additions, objectively the best scope in the game with no weakness, why would you use another? Now it's just a bunch of 1.5x clones walking around with no strategies or thought as to how they engage a gunfight.

Adding a shooting range was a decent implementation after years of people asking for one, but why was there a need to then remove T-hunt. You add something the community loves and then proceed to take away something the community has loved for years prior, it's not even pvp, it doesn't divide players or harm the matchmaking in any way it's just a strange decision. 

The new maps; reworked or not, and operators consistently being introduced don't seem great either, granted I haven't played enough of them but nobody seems to like them in anyway, they get banned almost instantly in every game. Fenrir's gadget just seems way too strong but worst of all just painful to go up against, you can hide it in a floor and the next minute an attacker is Stevie Wonder with little to no counterplay.

What even is the battle pass as well, I feel like i'm playing the harry the hamster browser game. it's not rewarding, you don't get the credits back and it's painful to look at and navigate. Not sure how they made it worse than it was before.

I used to love this game and part of me still does but the more time goes on it just gets worse. Casual is nowhere near as fun and Ranked is nowhere near as fair and rewarding. L's on all fronts.

I was excited to play this game but I went 'ubi-soft' really quick. It's not a game. It's tedium. It's bugged out bloatware. It's a waste of $7.99, yes I got it on sale and refunded it immediately after 35 minutes of work, bugs, dark patterns, and unskippable audio and cut-scenes.

The bloatware:
First, the game installs an unnecessary test server (50gb). Then it installs the launcher, forces you to create an account, and then installs battle eye, Ubisoft connect, Uplay, and adds TWO folders to your PICTURES directory. I have no idea how much **** it put on my PC, that's all I could find. Good luck getting ubisoft connect to uninstall (shoutout to a 2yo reddit comment > you need to hit 'quit' from the hidden windows tray icon in the carrot left of your volume controls).

The actual misery of trying to play this 'game':
I uninstalled the test server, then launched the game. Crashed (while running at 500fps) because it needed to reinstall all of the above after I removed the test server. Finally after 3 launch attempts it loads up and forces you to play what I assume to be about an hour of tutorial. Only made it 35 minutes before a bug forced me to restart the tutorial. Rappelling? Forget it. Left-handed/eyed gun HUD? Nope (It was a requested feature in 2018; did the devs add it? Why even ask lol). The rappelling glitching out and forcing me and others to restart an overengineered tutorial was the final straw. The tutorial is designed for toddlers to learn how to operate a gun and ping the ceiling, but not rappel apparently. Just play Overwatch or CSGO or Valorant. They're all individually leaps and bounds better than this game. Writing this review was a poor but acceptable solace received for you (pointing at ubisoft) wasting 35 minutes of my time. Ultimately it's our fault though. We're just too dumb and we keep buying ubisoft products. If gamers were smart, ubisoft wouldn't have succeeded as a franchise.

Rainbow Six Siege, developed by Ubisoft Montreal, stands as a testament to the evolution of tactical shooters. Since its release in 2015, it has captivated millions of players worldwide with its intense gameplay, strategic depth, and ever-expanding roster of operators. As a team-based multiplayer shooter, Rainbow Six Siege challenges players to outsmart and outmaneuver their opponents in high-stakes, close-quarters combat scenarios. Let's delve into the myriad facets that make Rainbow Six Siege one of the most beloved titles in the genre.

Gameplay:
At its core, Rainbow Six Siege revolves around the concept of asymmetrical warfare, where two teams of operators with unique abilities face off in tense, tactical encounters. Each round presents a dynamic puzzle, with attackers aiming to breach and secure an objective while defenders strive to fortify their position and repel the assault. The game's emphasis on environmental destruction adds a layer of realism and unpredictability, allowing players to breach walls, barricades, and floors to gain a tactical advantage.

The diverse roster of operators further enhances the depth of gameplay, with each operator bringing a distinct set of gadgets, weapons, and abilities to the battlefield. From breaching charges and reinforced walls to drones and surveillance cameras, the possibilities for strategic play are virtually endless. The game's tactical depth rewards coordination, communication, and adaptability, making teamwork essential for success.

Maps and Environments:
Rainbow Six Siege features a variety of meticulously designed maps, ranging from tightly enclosed urban environments to sprawling outdoor locales. Each map offers multiple routes, sightlines, and points of entry, encouraging players to devise creative strategies and adapt to ever-changing circumstances. Whether it's rappelling up the side of a skyscraper or breaching through a basement wall, the game's dynamic environments provide endless opportunities for emergent gameplay and memorable moments.

Operators and Customization:
With over 60 operators to choose from, Rainbow Six Siege offers a staggering amount of variety and customization. Operators are divided into different CTUs (Counter-Terrorist Units), each with its own unique gadgets and abilities. From the agile and stealthy operators of the SAS to the high-tech gadgets of the GIGN, there's an operator to suit every playstyle and preference.

In addition to choosing an operator, players can customize their loadouts with a wide array of weapons, attachments, and equipment. Whether you prefer a stealthy approach with suppressed weapons or a more aggressive playstyle with shotguns and explosives, the customization options allow for endless experimentation and personalization.

Community and Esports:
Rainbow Six Siege boasts a thriving community of dedicated players, with millions of active users and a vibrant esports scene. Regular updates, balance patches, and new content releases keep the game fresh and engaging, while events and seasonal challenges offer rewards and incentives for players to keep coming back.

The game's competitive scene has also flourished in recent years, with professional teams competing in tournaments and leagues around the world. The tactical depth and skill-based gameplay of Rainbow Six Siege make it a compelling esport to watch and follow, with high-stakes matches and clutch plays keeping viewers on the edge of their seats.

Conclusion:
Rainbow Six Siege is more than just a game; it's a constantly evolving, living ecosystem that continues to push the boundaries of competitive gaming. With its deep gameplay mechanics, diverse roster of operators, and thriving community, it offers endless hours of strategic fun for players of all skill levels. Whether you're coordinating with teammates to execute a flawless breach or outsmarting your opponents with cunning tactics, Rainbow Six Siege delivers an unparalleled multiplayer experience that is as exhilarating as it is rewarding. So gear up, choose your operators, and prepare for the ultimate test of skill and strategy in Rainbow Six Siege.

Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Siege - A Tense and Addictive Tactical Experience

Rating: â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜†

Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Siege, developed by Ubisoft, has solidified itself as a cornerstone in the tactical shooter genre, offering intense, team-based gameplay that demands strategic thinking and precise execution. While the game undeniably delivers a thrilling experience, the high stakes and competitive nature can, at times, lead to a sense of frustration and intensity that some may find draining.

The core of Rainbow Six Siege lies in its emphasis on realistic, close-quarters combat and destructible environments. The game's unique Operators, each with their specialized abilities, add a layer of depth to the tactical gameplay, encouraging diverse team compositions and strategic planning. The attention to detail in weapon mechanics and environmental destruction enhances the immersion, creating an atmosphere of tension and urgency.

The competitive nature of Rainbow Six Siege is both a strength and a potential drawback. The game demands constant vigilance, communication, and adaptability, creating an adrenaline-fueled experience that can be emotionally draining for players seeking a more casual gaming session. The learning curve is steep, and the pressure to perform at a high level may contribute to a sense of frustration for newcomers or those less experienced in tactical shooters.

The constant updates and additions to the game, including new Operators, maps, and game modes, showcase Ubisoft's commitment to keeping Rainbow Six Siege fresh and engaging. The evolving meta and strategic landscape add longevity to the experience, ensuring that dedicated players always have something new to explore.

The toxic behavior within the Rainbow Six Siege community has been a persistent issue. Instances of harassment, unsportsmanlike conduct, and occasional cheating can create a less-than-enjoyable environment. While Ubisoft has implemented measures to address toxicity, it remains an ongoing concern that can detract from the overall experience.

The monetization model, primarily centered around cosmetic microtransactions, allows players to customize their Operators and weapons without impacting gameplay. While this approach avoids pay-to-win scenarios, the allure of cosmetic items may contribute to the game's reputation as a "soul-sucking" experience for those who get drawn into the microtransaction ecosystem.

In conclusion, Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Siege delivers an exceptional and immersive tactical shooter experience that is both exhilarating and challenging. Its competitive nature and high stakes may not be suitable for everyone, as the intensity and potential for frustration can be draining. However, for those seeking a deep and strategic multiplayer experience, Rainbow Six Siege remains a benchmark in the genre, offering a gameplay experience that is as demanding as it is rewarding.

This review was written by ChatGPT:

Rainbow Six Siege: Where friendships are tested and walls are reinforced!

If you've ever dreamed of being part of a SWAT team but lack the physique, discipline, or overall ability to function as a cohesive unit, then Rainbow Six Siege is the game for you!

Picture this: You and your team of misfits are tasked with either rescuing a hostage or preventing a bomb from going off. Sounds simple, right? Wrong! Because in Siege, the only thing more fragile than your tactics is your ego.

Prepare yourself for the thrill of breaching a room, only to be swiftly taken out by a sneaky camper who's been patiently waiting in a corner for the past ten minutes. But fear not! You'll have plenty of opportunities to exact revenge when you respawn, only to fall victim to the same camper again. Ah, the circle of life... or should I say, the circle of "git gud."

And let's not forget the joy of communication! Who needs tactical callouts when you can just scream "He's in that room with the thingy!" and hope for the best? Bonus points if your teammates understand your unique blend of panic and confusion.

But don't let the steep learning curve discourage you. With enough dedication, you too can become a master at accidentally blowing up your own team with poorly placed explosives or barricades. It's all part of the fun!

So grab your reinforced walls, don your tactical gear, and get ready for a rollercoaster of emotions in Rainbow Six Siege. Just remember: in the world of Siege, the only thing more unpredictable than your opponents is your own ability to fail spectacularly. Enjoy

EDIT: Siege has changed quite a bit since I posted this and I feel obligated to update this so no one is fooled into thinking the strategy is still there (at least on a casual level). You see, Ubisoft has completely changed the casual gameplay and made it into a COD clone that's all about sweaty deathmatch rather than careful strategy. The only way to get the old casual experience is to play ranked, which for most people is something that requires a lot of time commitment and can be very toxic if you don't have 4 friends to play with. Ultimately I can't recommend this anymore, used to be my favorite game but now it's appealing to a much younger audience that wants a dopamine rush rather than thinking and strategy.

Old review:
My most played game on Steam. Despite Ubisoftâ€™s best efforts, I just canâ€™t stay away from Siege. Siege offers something very unique in the multiplayer shooter genre; it lets you be creative. One game mode doesnâ€™t get repetitive when thereâ€™s 4 locations on each map, each with myriad possibilities for the 65 different characters (with new ones being added every few months). The weighty gunplay, a fantastic destruction system, and layers upon layers of strategy make it something Iâ€™ll never get bored of. Here's the thing, as someone with over 700 hours on console, I have played my fair share of matches in this game. I took a long break from Siege for years after they nerfed ELA into the ground. The game does feel better now, but the fact that there are some maps that do not make it into Quick Match (formerly Casual) is ridiculous. There is in fact no way to play a map like Oregon or Theme Park with the Secure Area gamemode (my favourite over bomb). But if you used to play this on console and were thinking about getting it, I would recommend it. The game feels solid and with constant updates it is for sure worth it. If you are new to Siege, keep in mind this a very toxic game. Even more so on PC, just given that more people use voice chat and text chat (which obviously does not exist on console). Anyway, give this game a look, it is still the same game essentially 9 years later.

A multiplayer shooter that actually requires a team in order to win. You choose from a pool of operators with realistic skills and gadgets that all play a part in securing the objective, if someone in your team is an aim god you don't automatically win, you have to communicate and complement each other abilities. Tactics, strategies and the ability to gather information about the opponent is more important than the actual shooting.
 You can play Ranked, standard (ranked without points) and casual (less rounds), or you can play arcade which is just some fun mini games to test your aim and other things. You now also get access to a shooting range where you can test your loadout beforehand, a game against AI for you to train alone and a way to learn all maps in the game.
 The game is now better than ever for newcomers, and if your looking for a good multiplayer fps where after you spend lots of hours you are still learning new things and ways to get better then definitely buy this game

For lazy guys who can't/don't want to read - jump to the end(In short - don't).

Small footnote - never ever confuse "Tactical" and "Tacticool"
[b]Tactical[/b] (Interior > Exterior) - "art of arrangement", planning, "thought outstrips action", etc. 
   (a.k.a. try to predict enemy movement, patiently and quietly await the right moment for execution)
[b]Tacticool[/b] (Exterior > Interior)  - cool reload animations, smooth weapons, conversations, callouts and callsigns as if you ever were in Navy Seals or Rangers(overwhelming majority of those milsim guys never were there and never will get there even if they were willing to).
   (a.k.a. make up the worst plan possible, use military jargon, execute it in the worst manner possible, while still using military jargon, example - rush the building as if you were completely stripped of your sensory organs, get fragged in most obvious and open spot possible, but doing it [i]in style[/i] while screaming "I'm hit", "Enemy spotted", etc.)

Old Rainbow Six games were excellent not because they had those beefy reload animations, realistic graphics or cool and tough looking operators[spoiler](or a shitload of community-made porn)[/spoiler] but because of ability to plan any mission down to the smallest detail, to execute mission either in slow and thorough pace or in shock, percussive tempo(also, there was a possibility and sometimes a requirement of doing the mission while remaining unnoticed), to make sure every team member survives the mission and shows top performance during execution, because if they don't - they will be either heavily injured and not being able to participate in next couple of missions or gone for the rest of the game...

(should be read with outrageous french accent)

[i]"...on the frontlines of this strange war is the [u]counter-terrorism task force[/u] codenamed 'Rainbow'. Operating out of basis on both sides of the Atlantic, Rainbow operatives are ready to strike at a moment's notice anywhere on the globe. Although their existence is [u]secret[/u]*, their combined courage and vigilance have [u]saved the lives of millions[/u]..."[/i] (c) Rainbow Six: Rogue Spear intro
Tactical immersive shooter, with strong accent on cooperation, player's use of intelligence, with no second chance**, realistic threats and realistic solutions for them. And, of course, an easy-to-hate targets - terrorists who need to be given a severe punishment for their crimes...

[spoiler]But, unfortunately, developing stuff for little kids makes more money than developing games that require the use of brain. And that's why we see this instead of Rainbow Six: Patriots(a bit out of "tactical", but at least realistic):... [/spoiler]

Reality (after y3 it became even worse [up until year 8, where I stopped playing])
"It's freaking space aliens, man!"(c) Wolfenstein 2: New Colossus
Circus with airsoft guns(and those buff-nerf rollercoaster hills), overwatch-like operators (every op has at least 2 replacements), pink [b][u]camouflage[/u][/b]*** as such(really catches my eye after seeing "tactical" tag on this game's page and knowing about it's predecessors), unicorn helmets, anime stuff, pizza outfits, [b]people which are completely unable to use their sensory organs and just wasting time during rounds[/b] (sadly, like in any other online game), pros crying about realistic settings being too op (like it wasn't meant to be like this), devs ruining every single aspect of the game with their pro league pleasing updates, fuckton of preposterous bugs, errors, gadgets, backstories and, finally, an enormous, unstopping flood of shit coming each season with less and less things that can make me play this game any longer. 

Ubi Soft(it's current staff) are exterminating "Tactical" genre with the piece of garbage they called "[b][i]Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six[/i][/b]" game in favor of mainstreams and money.

The only cool thing(close to year 8) - some character, who said he was part of Rainbow unit before (or was leading it, judging by word combination "my unit"), almost quoted "Reality" paragraph of this review and then shot that psychotherapist guy. Let alone those fucking candy-shite/zombie-halloween/alien-invasion things*** that aren't supposed to be a matter of debate at event theme discussion for Tom Clancy game, you will see no such things in Ghost Recon, right?
UPD: The game is about counter-terrorism unit, but we will take away from players the [b]main[/b] part of the series - counter-terrorism operations, cause why not make fans any angrier?

 they will always know what's best for those who still engaged, disregarding amount of noise and disruption they produce(and totally not being able to analyze the situation that led them to being a spectator).

I have a pretty good amount of time in this game, I feel, enough to say that I don't think it's worth it for many people.
Is it fun? Yes. In those moments that click, I haven't had as much fun in a competitive first person shooter, ever.
But it also sucks. A lot. There's a lot of really cheap strategies, blatant meta, and a steep learning curve. Not only do you have to become aware of these, but you have to pray your teammates are as well. 

Which brings me to the largest issue with this game - it's community. 
You will get some cool, amazing people sometimes - dudes that are supportive, give call outs, etc. But more often than you get those, you get guys who refuse to listen to callouts or are genuinely toxic. Name calling, trolling, afk, and much, much more.

And finally... it's a ubisoft game. The progression is slow as fuck, unless you pay money.

Title: Rainbow Six Siege: A Game-Changer That Transformed My Life

Rainbow Six Siege isn't just a game; it's an experience that reshaped my perspective on gaming and left an indelible mark on my life. From the moment I delved into its intricate world of tactical gameplay, I knew I had stumbled upon something truly extraordinary. Ubisoft's masterpiece isn't merely a run-of-the-mill shooter; it's a meticulously crafted symphony of strategy, teamwork, and adrenaline-pumping action that has redefined the very essence of competitive gaming.

One of the most profound ways Rainbow Six Siege has impacted my life is through its emphasis on teamwork and communication. Unlike many other games where individual prowess reigns supreme, Siege teaches you that success hinges on collaboration and synergy with your teammates. Through countless hours spent coordinating strategies, devising intricate plans, and executing them flawlessly, I learned invaluable lessons in leadership, adaptability, and effective communication. These skills have not only enhanced my gaming experience but have also transcended into my personal and professional life, making me a more effective team player and leader in various aspects of life.

Furthermore, Rainbow Six Siege's dynamic gameplay constantly challenges players to think on their feet and devise creative solutions to overcome obstacles. Whether it's breaching a fortified objective, defending against a relentless assault, or outsmarting opponents in a tense standoff, every match presents a unique set of challenges that demand strategic thinking and quick decision-making. This constant mental stimulation has sharpened my cognitive abilities, improved my problem-solving skills, and instilled in me a sense of resilience and determination that extends far beyond the virtual battlefield.

Moreover, the Rainbow Six Siege community is unlike any other I've encountered in gaming. It's a diverse melting pot of players from all walks of life, united by their passion for tactical gameplay and shared experiences. Whether it's forming lasting friendships with fellow operators, engaging in spirited debates about strategies and tactics, or simply reveling in the thrill of victory together, the sense of camaraderie fostered within the Siege community is truly unparalleled. Through interactions with my fellow players, I've forged connections that have enriched my life and expanded my horizons in ways I never thought possible.

In conclusion, Rainbow Six Siege isn't just a game; it's a transformative experience that has left an indelible mark on my life. Through its emphasis on teamwork, strategic gameplay, and vibrant community, Siege has not only provided endless hours of entertainment but has also empowered me with invaluable life lessons and meaningful connections. For me, and countless others, Rainbow Six Siege isn't just the best game ever made; it's a lifestyle, a passion, and a testament to the incredible impact that gaming can have on our lives.

Been playing since 2016 so I have quite a bit of complaints about how much the game has gotten worse over the years. EDIT: I HAVE OVER 2500 HOURS, I USED TO PLAY ON XBOX. THIS REVIEW WAS WRITTEN ON 2/18/2024.

- Operation Health was the start of the downfall. Nothing good was fixed, and only created more issues.
- Operator hitboxes have been up and down over the last couple of years, but for the most part, have been fixed, but still can be insanely buggy.
- To be good, you used to have to learn strategies that would give you the edge on the other team. Now its a TDM meta, so its better to rush corners or fast peak. Ex: If your holding an angle and someone swings you, you have half a second less time to react then they do. At higher levels, especially on PC, this makes it nearly impossible for you to win the gunfight. 
- Operator pool is very very diluted. All Ubi cares about is money, so they just make new ops that make other ops gadgets and guns useless. 
- Competitive play requires minimal skill to achieve higher ranks. It is all about grinding and who plays the most during that season. On top of that, when reset, you can play about 20 games until you lose and gain same mmr per match, but since you start in copper, you will be like silver by the time the game starts putting you against the players you were playing in Plat or Diamond last season.
- Gamemodes suck, they ruined cas by making less prep phase which is a huge disadvantage for many different operators on defense. It also doesn't help new players at all because it teaches them bad placement for reinforcements, barricades, etc. 

Thats pretty much it. The fact that I spent a whopping 5 minutes writing this review just goes to show how bad this game has become. I could have actually spent more time on this and gone into things more in detail, but I don't really have the patience. 

All in all, don't waste your money on this terrible Ubi game unless you are just buying it to play with friends and have fun in random game modes.

Asian food is not to everyone's taste but give these spicy and sticky Korean chicken wings a try, they make ideal finger food for a buffet, but don't forget the napkins!

Recipe:
Sticky Korean chicken wings

Ingredients

For the chicken
500g chicken wings
large chunk of ginger, finely grated
50g cornflour
vegetable oil, for frying
sesame seeds and sliced spring onion, to serve
For the sauce
6 tbsp dark brown sugar
2 tbsp gochujang (Korean chilli paste)
2 tbsp soy sauce
2 large garlic cloves, crushed
small piece ginger, grated
2 tsp sesame oil

Method

STEP 1
To make the sauce, put all the ingredients in a saucepan and simmer gently until syrupy, so around 3-4 mins. Take off the heat and set aside.

STEP 2
Season the chicken wings with salt, pepper and the grated ginger. Toss the chicken with the cornflour until completely coated.

STEP 3
Heat about 2cm of vegetable oil in a large frying pan over a medium/high heat. Fry the chicken wings for 8-10 mins until crisp, turning halfway. Remove from the oil and place on kitchen paper. Leave to cool slightly (around 2 mins).

STEP 4
Reheat the sauce, and toss the crispy chicken wings in it. Tip into a bowl and top with the sesame seeds and sliced spring onions.


Nutrition: per serving

kcal
487
fat
24g
saturates
4g
carbs
48g
sugars
35g
fibre
1g
protein
20g
salt
1.8g

The Troubling Realities of Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Siege

Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Siege, a popular tactical shooter video game developed by Ubisoft, has garnered a massive player base and significant attention in the gaming community since its release in 2015. However, beneath its flashy graphics and intense gameplay lies a host of issues that make it a deeply flawed experience for many players. From toxic behavior to technical shortcomings, Rainbow Six Siege presents numerous challenges that undermine its potential as a truly enjoyable gaming experience.

One of the most glaring problems with Rainbow Six Siege is its toxic community. In online multiplayer matches, players often encounter verbal abuse, harassment, and other forms of toxic behavior from teammates and opponents alike. The game's reliance on teamwork and communication exacerbates this issue, as players are frequently subjected to criticism and hostility if they make mistakes or fail to perform up to expectations. This toxic environment not only ruins the gaming experience for many players but also drives away newcomers who may be deterred by the negativity.

Furthermore, Rainbow Six Siege suffers from numerous technical issues that hinder gameplay and frustrate players. From server outages and connectivity problems to glitches and bugs, the game is rife with technical shortcomings that disrupt matches and diminish the overall enjoyment of the experience. Frequent crashes, lag spikes, and other performance issues plague both the console and PC versions of the game, leading to widespread frustration among players who expect a smooth and seamless gaming experience.

Another significant issue with Rainbow Six Siege is its imbalanced gameplay and flawed mechanics. Despite attempts by the developers to balance the game through patches and updates, certain operators and weapons remain overpowered, while others are underpowered or underutilized. This imbalance creates an unfair playing field where certain strategies and tactics dominate, leaving little room for experimentation or creative expression. Moreover, the game's reliance on microtransactions and loot boxes to unlock new operators and cosmetics further exacerbates this issue, as players are forced to either grind for hours or spend real money to access content that should be available from the start.

In addition to its gameplay issues, Rainbow Six Siege has also been criticized for its lackluster single-player experience. While the game offers a series of solo missions and situations, they pale in comparison to the depth and complexity of the multiplayer modes. As a result, players who prefer to play alone or who lack reliable internet connections are left with a subpar gaming experience that fails to justify the game's high price tag.

Overall, Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Siege falls short of its potential due to a myriad of issues that detract from the overall experience. From its toxic community and technical shortcomings to its imbalanced gameplay and lackluster single-player content, the game fails to deliver on the promise of tactical shooter excellence. While some players may still find enjoyment in Rainbow Six Siege despite its flaws, it's clear that significant improvements are needed to address the game's numerous shortcomings and restore faith in its long-term viability as a competitive multiplayer experience. Until then, Rainbow Six Siege will continue to struggle to maintain its relevance in an increasingly crowded gaming landscape.

I've never left a review for a video game and specifically on Steam. I know Ubisoft will never see this so here goes. This game is the epitome of, "Let's make this really popular game as a AAA studio and call it great! Let's never fix issues that really matter and also on top of that, make it run like shit because our servers are awful!". Never in my life have I played a video game like Rainbow Six Siege. That is a good and a bad thing. In the beginning, I really enjoyed this game, that's not to say that I still don't but I hate it now. This game is an actual Love-Hate relationship. They constantly want to add new shit without the consideration of whether the content they are releasing is actually good. Most of the time it's not. Especially now. I refuse to sit and listen to people who say there's been an upgrade over the years to this game because that's a straight up lie. Ubisoft, if you ever see this review, fuck you from the bottom of my heart. Your servers are trash. Your game runs like trash at the most random times and makes no sense. Your game refuses to operate properly when it matters most. Now I know a lot of you are thinking, "Mouse, why are you being a little whiny bitch? Why don't you just play a good game instead?", you'd be right in assuming these things but I still love the feel of accomplishment this game gives when I achieve new levels of skill. It's rewarding. But what isn't rewarding is the blatant neglect that these shitheads at Ubisoft show in their game. Save your money, save your time, and by all means....please save your sanity. This game is not worth the amount of stress it will give you. 

Stay safe and stay away from this game. Best wishes, Mouse.

Playing Rainbow Six Siege, like any video game, can have various effects on an individual's mental well-being. It's important to note that these effects can vary from person to person, and many players engage with the game without experiencing negative mental side effects. However, here are some potential aspects to consider:

Stress and Pressure: Rainbow Six Siege is a tactical first-person shooter that requires quick thinking, strategic planning, and precise execution. The intense nature of the gameplay can lead to stress and pressure, especially during high-stakes moments. Some players may find this exhilarating, while others may feel overwhelmed.

Frustration and Anger: The competitive nature of Rainbow Six Siege can lead to frustration and anger, particularly when facing challenging opponents, experiencing in-game losses, or encountering perceived unfairness. This emotional response can impact one's mood and overall mental state.

Communication Skills: The game heavily emphasizes communication and teamwork. Positive interactions with teammates can enhance communication skills and foster a sense of camaraderie. On the other hand, negative experiences with toxic players or a lack of effective communication can have detrimental effects on mental well-being.

Concentration and Focus: Success in Rainbow Six Siege often requires a high level of concentration and focus. Extended gaming sessions without breaks may lead to mental fatigue, affecting cognitive performance both in-game and in other areas of life.

Social Isolation: While Rainbow Six Siege offers opportunities for social interaction through online multiplayer, excessive gaming can contribute to social isolation if it leads to neglect of real-world relationships or responsibilities.

It's essential for players to be mindful of their gaming habits and how they impact their mental health. Setting reasonable time limits, taking breaks, maintaining a healthy balance between gaming and other activities, and being aware of emotional responses during gameplay are crucial steps to mitigate potential negative effects.

If individuals find that their gaming habits are negatively impacting their mental well-being, seeking support from friends, family, or mental health professionals is advisable. Additionally, taking breaks, practicing self-care, and maintaining a healthy lifestyle are essential for overall mental health, regardless of one's engagement with video games.

Title: Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six: Where Strategy Meets Action - Game Review

Hey there, fellow gamers! If you're into heart-pounding action and strategic gameplay, then you've got to check out Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six. Developed by Ubisoft, this game is all about putting your tactical skills to the test in intense counter-terrorism operations.

When you dive into Rainbow Six, get ready to step into the boots of elite operatives from around the world. You'll be taking on missions that require serious planning and teamwork. Seriously, communication is key here â€“ whether you're coordinating your breach points or covering your teammate's back, you'll need to work together to come out on top.

One of the coolest things about Rainbow Six is the environmental destruction. Seriously, you can blow holes in walls, blast through floors â€“ you name it. It adds a whole new layer of strategy to the game, letting you get creative with your approach to each mission.

And let's talk about the visuals and sound. The game looks amazing, with detailed environments that really draw you in. And the sound design? It's top-notch. Every gunshot and footstep adds to the tension, keeping you on the edge of your seat.

Now, I know what you're thinking â€“ what about the story? Well, while Rainbow Six is mostly focused on multiplayer, the single-player campaign still delivers. It's all about sacrifice, heroism, and the high-stakes world of counter-terrorism.

And speaking of multiplayer, there's plenty of replayability here. Whether you're diving into ranked matches or just goofing around in casual play, there's always a new challenge waiting for you.

So, if you're looking for a game that'll get your adrenaline pumping and your brain working overtime, look no further than Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six. Trust me, you won't be disappointed. thanks chatgpt for the review

Every time I play this thing, it feels like im being grabbed by the neck and being forced to play. What I really love about the game is:
 
Gameplay Mechanics:
Rainbow Six Siege is renowned for its strategic depth and teamwork-centric gameplay. The emphasis on tactics, communication, and environmental destruction sets it apart from other shooters. The diverse roster of Operators with unique abilities adds complexity and variety to matches. However, the steep learning curve may alienate some newcomers, as mastering maps, operators, and strategies requires time and patience.

Graphics and Audio:
The game boasts detailed environments and realistic sound design, enhancing immersion and tactical awareness. Visuals are crisp, and the attention to detail in character models and weapon design is commendable. The audio cues play a crucial role in gameplay, alerting players to approaching enemies or environmental hazards.

Content and Updates:
Ubisoft has been consistent in providing post-launch support through regular updates, including new Operators, maps, and gameplay tweaks. The evolving meta keeps the experience fresh, and the commitment to fixing bugs and addressing community feedback is evident. However, some players have criticized the microtransaction model for cosmetics and Operators, arguing that it can feel predatory or grind-heavy.

Community and Multiplayer Experience:
Rainbow Six Siege thrives on its vibrant community and competitive multiplayer scene. The game encourages teamwork and coordination, fostering a dedicated player base. However, toxicity and cheating remain persistent issues, impacting the overall experience for some players. Ubisoft's efforts to combat toxicity through reporting systems and bans have seen mixed success.

Single-player and PVE Content:
While Rainbow Six Siege primarily focuses on multiplayer, it offers limited single-player and PVE content through situations and terrorist hunt modes. While these modes can be enjoyable for practice or casual play, they lack the depth and longevity of the multiplayer experience.

In summary, Rainbow Six Siege offers a unique and engaging tactical shooter experience with deep gameplay mechanics, frequent updates, and a dedicated community. However, its steep learning curve, microtransactions, and ongoing issues with toxicity may deter some players. Ultimately, its appeal hinges on a player's preference for strategic gameplay and willingness to invest time into mastering its intricacies.

This game fundamentally misunderstands what a competitive rank should be, namely a means instead of an end.
You rank up after winning 2 matches which means low skilled players constantly have to face high ranks after winning a couple of fun, close matches against opponents of the same skill. Not to even mention ubisofts sole goal is to make the game less enjoyable through constant ''balances'' and ''patches''. I only play this now because my friends like it but it is insane to me that a game as unplayable as this has a solid playerbase. Also the fact that this game is advertised as tactical is a joke. The only positive is the fun gunplay and slightly above average anti-cheat which is lacking in actually good games like csgo.

Paralympic shooting, also known as shooting Para sport (Para Shooting), is an adaptation of shooting sports for competitors with disabilities. Shooting is a test of accuracy and control, in which competitors use pistols or rifles to fire a series of shots at a stationary target. Each shot is worth a maximum score of 10.9 points. Athletes use .22 caliber rifles, pistols and .177 caliber air guns (compressed air or pneumatic). Paralympic shooting first appeared in the Summer Paralympics at the 1976 Toronto Games.

All I have to say is this is such an awesome game. I've been playing on and off since 2020 and I always find myself coming back to it. There's an endless stream of content and play styles that people can use and it makes the game extremely unique to most FPS style games nowadays. The amount of operators you can unlock and learn is unfathomable. I haven't even unlocked half of them. The maps are extremely detailed and fun to play on. The game modes seem as if they get even more fun as you play them. Every game leaves me on the edge of my chair waiting to see if my team's going to win. All and all, this an amazing game and I would suggest that everyone tries it out at least once. It's not for everyone, but at least you can say you've tried it.

The game itself is great. I love the operators and the gameplay is awesome. The only 2 problems are that on Ranked mode, there's a TON of hackers (filled to the brim with them), so... good luck winning anything when the other team can see through walls and can kill you on one shot to the head without you even being able to retaliate. The other issue are the servers themselves which are trash. It sometimes kicks you out of a match because of an "error" and then ban you for it. Or sometimes it will just not allow you to get in a match with the rest of your team and then ban you because of it and there's nothing you can do.

In short, the game is good as long as you stay away from the Ranked and "Standard" modes since there are a lot of hackers there and the servers are buggy as hell. (I've played for countless hours before I got it on Steam. I was playing it directly from Ubisoft Connect's launcher using XBOX Gamepass)

For all the new players buying this on sale!!!
Though this game was really fun and simple in newcomer playlist, it isn't quite like that when you go try ranked the first time at level 50. Here are some (probably all) of the possibilities you might encounter (unless ur smurfing duh):
1. Get called out "Oh my god we got a level 50 in our team :///"
2. Gets 360 headshotted (players under Y6 would probably die immediately because friendly fire is already on during prep phase back then) by your own tm8 while reinforcing walls (which was supposed to be rotations walls). Oh yea and especially next to a mira window you should try that (not recommended)
3. Get shot directly after spawning (it's called a spawnpeek duh)
4. You might think ur doing the right thing, but NO the 4.5 K/D ex-Diamond level 250 with 1297207 hrs playtime on ur team will always yell at you when your not playing according to what they want you to play. You are also forced to use a specific operator which u might not have unlocked yet because you're new (except u have a CEO daddy and a model mommy).
5. If you happen to be a female wanting to play casually, REFUND THE GAME IMMEDIATELY, orr you can go play against bots and quick matches which have more chill players. But if you're good then maybe that's okay just don't reveal ur self or even use ur mic.
6. The urge to punch your gaming accessories is very high every ranked game and increases by 10% chance after every rank up

Good luck new players !!! ;)

After playing ranked, I have never wanted commit more self harm in my life. The hit registration, the servers, and the community if more stressful than, being fired, owing the IRS 30,000, and being physically incapable of being able to afford house payments. The changes UBI has made to the game have gotten increasingly horrid, and I personally feel if they handed it over to LITERALLY A THREE YEAR OLD, it would be worlds better. I will play this every day of my life, but do so angrily.

Unplayable, full of cheaters online with fly hackers in god mode speeding around the map insta kill you through walls, dev's don't play the game they randomly balance stuff that nobody asked for. Cheap weekend is hacker weekend. If you get banned by mistake ubi doesn't care the support just has a pre-script written out about how they don't give an F about you coz you're just a number. 

They used to do 1 map + 4 new weapons + 2 operators now it's 1 map rework, 1 operator, no guns and they charge full price for a season pass which is not even half the content. Every season that comes out is buggier and buggier somehow, honestly feels like the skeleton crew. 

I used to love this game but even since the original devs left they ruined it. Bugs with shields have been in the game since year 1, they're changing/reworking now but the devs don't understand why they're bad in the first place so they're buffing them in other ways instead of asking the community what they'd like to see/implemented. 

They're removing old mechanics in the game which made the game fun/unique like a character used to have a unique interaction with another character (Ela + Zofia) but the devs dumb the game down so it's TDM meta turn your brain off and shoot the enemy after everyone complained about the game being "Too heavily gadget meta" which is what the game is meant to be about. 

Dev's combine old characters to make new characters instead of coming up with something unique that people have been asking for they're trying to hit a "100 charters" in the game but when they're combining 2 chracters to make 1 and then just giving it to the other side attack or defence yeah very boring.

Dev's when they "Fix" it is not an indefinite fix, bugs either come back because they're not patched properly, mechanics like drop shooting gets removed which is a good thing but you can still do it instead of entirely outright removing as it should be. Honestly with this game being one of Ubisofts top games besides being addictive tacticle shooter there is nothing going for it anymore.

My final review score is 4/10 - DO NOT PLAY, HEAVILY AVOID AND DO NOT LISTEN TO ANYONE ELSE TRUST.

Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Siege (R6 Siege) is a tactical first-person shooter that has firmly established itself as a staple in the multiplayer gaming landscape since its release in December 2015. Developed by Ubisoft Montreal, this game takes the beloved Tom Clancy franchise to new heights with its intense and strategic gameplay.

Gameplay (10/10):
The heart and soul of R6 Siege lie in its unparalleled gameplay. Set in various real-world locations, players assume the roles of elite counter-terrorism operators, each with a unique set of skills and gadgets. The game focuses on close-quarters combat, destructible environments, and strategic decision-making. Matches are 5v5, emphasizing teamwork, communication, and precise execution of plans.

The diverse roster of operators, divided into different CTU (Counter Terrorism Unit) factions, brings a refreshing variety to gameplay. Whether you prefer breaching walls with Sledge, setting traps with Frost, or gathering intel with Valkyrie, there's an operator that suits every playstyle. The constant addition of new operators and maps through seasonal updates keeps the game fresh and ensures a dynamic experience for both newcomers and seasoned players.

Realistic and Destructible Environments (9/10):
Rainbow Six Siege is renowned for its realistic and destructible environments. Almost every surface in the game is destructible, allowing for creative and unexpected strategies. Reinforce walls, breach through floors, and create sightlines that give your team the upper hand. The destruction adds an extra layer of depth to the tactical aspects of the game, making every match feel dynamic and unpredictable.

Graphics and Sound (8/10):
While not the most visually stunning game in its genre, R6 Siege boasts realistic character models, detailed maps, and impressive lighting effects. The audio design is exceptional, with distinct sounds for footsteps, gunfire, and environmental cues. The sound plays a crucial role in gameplay, as being able to identify enemy movements or gadget deployment can be the difference between success and failure.

Learning Curve (7/10):
R6 Siege has a steep learning curve, and new players may find themselves overwhelmed initially. The intricate map layouts, diverse operators, and strategic nuances can be challenging to grasp. However, this learning curve contributes to the game's long-term appeal, rewarding players who invest time in honing their skills and understanding the intricacies of each operator and map.

Community and Esports (10/10):
Rainbow Six Siege has cultivated a dedicated and passionate community. Regular updates, balance changes, and a commitment to esports have kept the player base engaged. The Pro League and major tournaments showcase high-level gameplay and strategies, inspiring players to improve and adopt advanced tactics.

Conclusion:
Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Siege is a must-buy for fans of tactical shooters and those seeking a competitive multiplayer experience. Its deep and strategic gameplay, combined with a constantly evolving roster of operators and maps, ensures that no two matches are alike. While the learning curve may be steep, the reward is an unparalleled sense of accomplishment as you master the art of siege warfare. With a thriving community and a commitment to ongoing support from Ubisoft, Rainbow Six Siege continues to be a top-tier multiplayer experience years after its initial release.

One Piece is an absolutely flawless show, with no flaws or mistakes ever present. Everything is where it should be, all characters are always true to themselves it has no plotholes and excels in everything, effectively putting it at 10/10, possible even above the scale, at 11/10. One Piece is factually flawless and the true representative of what peak fiction is. Given that One Piece is a series with no plotholes, flawless and entertaining narrative, amazingly real characters a complete and perfect score when it comes to action, and unparalleled messages, it stands objectively above all fictional works in terms of everything. One Piece is flawless as every aspect and every element across its narrative is perfectly placed. One Piece doesn't waste characters (not every character introduced has to be a world changer, characters serve a narrative purpose that can be simple and brief or long and very compelling). All apparent plotholes and contradictions are well explained if the reader has minimal comprehension. One Piece is a flawless show, with no imperfections or mistakes ever present. Everything is where it should be, all characters are always veridical to themselves it has no plotholes and excels in everything, efficaciously putting it at 10/10 rating. One Piece is factually impeccable and the veridical representative of what peak fiction is. Given that One Piece is a series with no plotholes, impeccable and regaling narrative, astonishingly authentic characters a consummate and perfect score when it comes to action, and unparalleled messages, it stands objectively above all  fictional works in terms of everything. One Piece is an extremely complex anime & manga which requires the viewer to focus on the slight details to get it at its fullest. Regardless, One Piece is by far the most enjoyable animanga ever created. One Piece is top tier. One Piece is clearly the best anime ever made and is a masterpiece and is the greatest anime of all time. One Piece is better. One Piece, no anime will ever be better. The best series ever created, best story best fights, best characters, best backstories, best themes, best antagonists, best worldbuilding, best everything. No matter what, no anime can top what One Piece has done in every single way. One Piece is still the greatest, was the greatest and will be the greatest anime ever, One Piece is indeed the best. One Piece has perfectly fleshed out characters, incredible worldbuilding, the best fights, flawless storyline and is the best animanga ever created. One Piece is the best show out there, deep, emotional, interesting, clever and funny, a complete story with great enigmas in ever amazing world. Just how amazingly relatable the backstories are the expertise in how Oda builds empathy for his characters is second to none. One Piece is a great story with a fantastic protagonist, its arcs gradually progress as the stakes get higher, the knowledge gets more vast, and the characters evolve, resulting in a great plot escalation. One Piece has a work of art of a narrative (with clever turns moments of suspense, sadness, joy, defeat, victory turns and surprises) worldbuilding (full of diverse, clever and sophisticated elements that form a distinctive and complex logic that reigns its universe, and multiple nations with individual and remarkably different features that set them apart in more than one way). Characters (relatable but special, understandable, with great development, inherent inner conflicts and good evolution and character development) combat system (complex but with logic, very varied and balanced). One Piece has a great balance of plot driven narrative and character driven narrative, in a way the actions of characters are always related or going for the ultimate goal, while also helping the surrounding stories and plot develop, in a natural way. The plot of One Piece is a great way to explore and get the best of its fantastic worldbuilding while keeping the story focused and relevant, it all combines into a great plotline in which past and present events are linked by the brilliant strategists of the show.

Rainbow Six Siege stands as a pinnacle in the realm of tactical shooters, offering an adrenaline-fueled blend of strategy, teamwork, and intense combat encounters. Developed by Ubisoft Montreal and released in 2015, the game has continued to evolve, captivating players with its ever-expanding roster of operators, dynamic gameplay mechanics, and robust community-driven esports scene.

Gameplay:
At its core, Rainbow Six Siege revolves around team-based skirmishes between attackers and defenders in various objective-based scenarios. Each round presents a unique challenge, requiring careful planning, communication, and execution. The game's destructible environments add an extra layer of depth, allowing for creative strategies and emergent gameplay moments.

Operators and Gadgets:
One of Siege's defining features is its diverse roster of operators, each equipped with unique gadgets and abilities. From breaching walls to deploying traps, the operators offer a wide range of playstyles, encouraging players to experiment and adapt to different situations. The constant addition of new operators through seasonal updates keeps the meta fresh and ensures there's always something new to discover.

Maps and Environments:
Siege boasts a variety of meticulously designed maps, ranging from cramped urban environments to sprawling compounds. Each map offers its own set of challenges and opportunities, requiring players to master the intricacies of layout and verticality. The destructibility of the environments adds a dynamic element to gameplay, allowing for strategic breaches and unexpected flanking routes.

Community and Esports:
Beyond its compelling gameplay, Rainbow Six Siege thrives on its vibrant community and thriving esports scene. Regular updates, events, and tournaments keep the player base engaged, while the Pro League showcases the highest level of competition in the game. The dedication of both developers and players has cultivated a passionate community, fostering camaraderie and competition alike.

Conclusion:
In conclusion, Rainbow Six Siege delivers an unparalleled tactical shooter experience that continues to captivate players worldwide. With its emphasis on teamwork, strategy, and skillful execution, the game offers endless opportunities for thrilling gameplay moments. Whether you're breaching barricades or defending objectives, Siege remains a must-play title for fans of tactical shooters and competitive gaming alike.

(OLD INFO EDIT AT BOTTOM) As someone who has played over 1000+ Hours of this game, overall, i have to say no. I've played this game for a long time, and there's still too many bugs after Four years for me to write a perfect review. This game is good. It's a tactical first-person shooter, and it's unique. It's a fun great game up until you encounter many of the bugs that have been in the game since year one. Between the Massive amount of game-breaking bugs, and audio bugs, which have been around for a very long time, i can't put a good review up. Ubisoft doesn't listen to their players. They decide what they want to do with the game themselves. They show close to no support for the player community and it's breathtaking how a game can become so big, yet give such an unpolished performance. That's not to say this game isn't worth your time, it very much is just that. worth your time if this is what you're in to. It's just very frustrating how simple bugs have never been fixed or worked with, yet the whole community complains about them.

EDIT!: After another 781 hours to be exact, and somewhere about 5 years later, i have come back to the game and it seems that most of the small annoying bugs have been fixed finally after all these years!

It's a good team-based shooter game, fun to play with friends, though I would not recommend it if you have never played it before. 

The servers are terrible, and the new penalty system gets me a suspension at least once a week because of the servers crashing. Ubisoft has promised improvement but does not deliver. The new matchmaking system in ranked is a disaster; it's very unbalanced, and I can never seem to meet anyone with the same skill level as myself. On top of that, most matches you enter is either toxic because someone has gotten upset over being killed or just for the hell of it. If there is no toxicity, there is often no communication, which is important in a team-based shooter.

If you haven't bought this game already, I would suggest investing your time into something else.

Rainbow Six Siege has solidified its status as one of the premier tactical shooters in the gaming landscape, captivating millions of players worldwide with its unique blend of intense action, strategic depth, and dynamic gameplay. From its inception, the game has continually evolved, refining its mechanics, expanding its content, and fostering a thriving community that remains deeply committed to its success.

At the heart of Rainbow Six Siege's appeal lies its emphasis on teamwork and communication. Unlike traditional shooters where individual prowess often reigns supreme, Siege places a premium on coordination and cooperation among teammates. Whether you're breaching a reinforced wall, coordinating a hostage rescue, or defending an objective from enemy incursions, success in Siege hinges on effective collaboration and synergy with your squadmates.

One of the game's most defining features is its diverse roster of operators, each equipped with unique gadgets, weapons, and abilities. From elite counter-terrorism units to rogue operatives, the operators in Siege offer a wealth of tactical options and strategic possibilities. Whether you prefer the stealthy reconnaissance of Valkyrie, the explosive breaching power of Ash, or the gadget manipulation of Thatcher, there's an operator to suit every playstyle and preference.

The depth of Siege's gameplay extends beyond its diverse operator roster to its meticulously crafted maps and environments. Each map presents its own set of challenges and opportunities, from multi-level structures to open-air courtyards, forcing players to adapt their tactics and strategies on the fly. Whether you're navigating the tight corridors of the Hereford Base or battling amidst the chaotic streets of Favela, every map in Siege offers a unique and immersive gameplay experience.

In addition to its engaging multiplayer modes, Siege also features a robust single-player experience through its Terrorist Hunt mode and Situations missions. These solo and cooperative challenges offer players the opportunity to hone their skills, familiarize themselves with the game's mechanics, and earn rewards to unlock new operators and gear. Whether you're a seasoned veteran looking to sharpen your skills or a newcomer seeking to learn the ropes, Siege provides ample opportunities for both.

Furthermore, Rainbow Six Siege has cultivated a passionate and dedicated community that continues to drive the game's growth and longevity. From pro players and content creators to casual enthusiasts, the Siege community is united by a shared passion for tactical gameplay and competitive camaraderie. Whether it's sharing strategies, discussing balance changes, or simply celebrating epic moments, the Siege community serves as a vibrant hub of activity and engagement.

The game's developer, Ubisoft Montreal, deserves praise for its ongoing commitment to supporting and expanding Rainbow Six Siege. Since its launch in 2015, the game has received regular updates, patches, and content drops, introducing new operators, maps, modes, and quality-of-life improvements. This dedication to post-launch support has not only kept the game fresh and exciting but also fostered a sense of trust and goodwill among the player base.

Moreover, Siege's esports scene has flourished, with the game becoming a staple of the competitive gaming circuit. From major tournaments like the Six Invitational to grassroots community events, Siege esports offer thrilling spectacles of skill, strategy, and teamwork. The game's emphasis on tactical depth and dynamic gameplay lends itself well to competitive play, making it a favorite among both players and spectators alike.

Beyond its gameplay mechanics and competitive scene, Rainbow Six Siege has also made strides in promoting diversity and inclusion within the gaming community. The game features a diverse cast of operators representing a wide range of nationalities, backgrounds, and identities. Furthermore, Ubisoft has taken steps to address issues of toxicity and harassment within the community, implementing measures to promote a more welcoming and inclusive environment for all players.

In terms of technical prowess, Rainbow Six Siege continues to impress with its stunning visuals, immersive sound design, and smooth gameplay mechanics. From the intricate details of its destructible environments to the visceral impact of its weapons and explosions, Siege delivers a sensory experience that is both exhilarating and immersive. Whether you're navigating the chaos of a firefight or executing a meticulously planned breach, every moment in Siege feels intense and impactful.

The game's longevity is further bolstered by its robust progression system, which rewards players with experience points, renown, and in-game currency for their achievements and contributions. Whether you're winning matches, completing challenges, or participating in events, there are always new rewards to unlock, operators to recruit, and gear to customize. This sense of progression and personalization adds depth and replay value to Siege, keeping players invested in the long term.

Furthermore, Rainbow Six Siege has proven itself to be a pioneer in the realm of live-service gaming, setting a new standard for ongoing support and content delivery. Through its seasonal updates, themed events, and limited-time modes, Siege provides a steady stream of new content and experiences to keep players engaged and entertained. Whether it's introducing new operators, balancing gameplay mechanics, or overhauling maps, Ubisoft remains committed to evolving and improving Siege for years to come.

In addition to its multiplayer offerings, Siege also boasts a robust suite of community tools and features that empower players to create, share, and discover content. From custom game modes and player-created maps to fan-made artwork and videos, the Siege community is a treasure trove of creativity and innovation. Whether you're looking to showcase your skills, collaborate with fellow players, or simply find inspiration, there's no shortage of ways to get involved and make your mark in Siege.

Another key strength of Rainbow Six Siege is its accessibility and inclusivity, with options and features designed to accommodate players of all skill levels and abilities. Whether you're a seasoned veteran or a newcomer to the genre, Siege offers a range of tutorials, guides, and matchmaking options to help you get started and improve your skills. From casual playlists and newcomer playlists to ranked matches and custom games, there's a mode for every level of player to enjoy.

Moreover, Siege's commitment to player feedback and community engagement sets it apart as a developer that truly listens to its audience. Through forums, social media channels, and live streams, Ubisoft Montreal maintains an open dialogue with the player base, soliciting feedback, addressing concerns, and sharing insights into the game's development process. This transparent and collaborative approach fosters a sense of trust and partnership between the developers and the community, ensuring that Siege continues to evolve in response to player needs and preferences.

Furthermore, Rainbow Six Siege serves as a testament to the power of collaboration and cross-platform play, bringing together players from diverse backgrounds and platforms to share in the thrill of tactical combat. Whether you're playing on PC, console, or even mobile devices, Siege offers seamless cross-platform functionality, allowing players to connect and compete with friends and rivals across different platforms and ecosystems. This inclusivity and accessibility further strengthen the game's community and ensure that everyone has the opportunity to participate and enjoy the experience.
